text: <https://underround.wordpress.com/2017/04/14/betfairlightweight-v1-0/>

attachments.title: betfairlightweight v1.0
attachments.text:
With the help of some contributors betfairlightweight has now reached version 1. Lightweight is a python wrapper which provides an interface to the Betfair API. In order to demonstrate  some of the features I have created an initial example/tutorial similar to this great tutorial that got me started in 2014.
All code can be found in the example section, any issues feel free to comment or join the slack group.
Requirements:
python (2 or 3)
betfair account + API key
Install:

pip install betfairlightweight

Part 1:
Code below details how to create a trading instance, login, print the session token and then logout.

import betfairlightweight

# create trading instance
trading = betfairlightweight.APIClient('username', 'password', app_key='appKey')

# login
trading.login()

print(trading.session_token)

# logout
trading.logout()

Part 2:
In order to get the event type id for horse racing a ‘list event type‘ request is required, here you can see how the ‘market filter‘ is imported and used. Behind the scenes lightweight turns the filter into json which is then sent to betfair. Lightweight then returns a list of ‘EventTypeResult‘ already converted into a python object rather than the json returned from the API.

import betfairlightweight
from betfairlightweight import filters

# create trading instance
trading = betfairlightweight.APIClient('username', 'password', app_key='appKey')

# login
trading.login()

# make event type request to find horse racing event type
horse_racing_event_type_id = trading.betting.list_event_types(
    filter=filters.market_filter(
        text_query='Horse Racing'
    )
)

# returns one result
print(horse_racing_event_type_id)

for event_type in horse_racing_event_type_id:
    # prints id, name and market count
    print(
        event_type.event_type.id, event_type.event_type.name, event_type.market_count
    )
    horse_racing_id = event_type.event_type.id

# logout
trading.logout()

Part 3:
In order to get catalogue data a ‘list market catalogue‘ request is required, this returns market level and runner level data depending on the ‘market projection‘ used.

import betfairlightweight
from betfairlightweight import filters

# create trading instance
trading = betfairlightweight.APIClient('username', 'password', app_key='appKey')

# login
trading.login()

# make event type request to find horse racing event type
horse_racing_event_type_id = trading.betting.list_event_types(
    filter=filters.market_filter(
        text_query='Horse Racing'
    )
)

# returns one result
print(horse_racing_event_type_id)

for event_type in horse_racing_event_type_id:
    # prints id, name and market count
    print(
        event_type.event_type.id, event_type.event_type.name, event_type.market_count
    )
    horse_racing_id = event_type.event_type.id

    # list all horse racing market catalogues
    market_catalogues = trading.betting.list_market_catalogue(
        filter=filters.market_filter(
            event_type_ids=[horse_racing_id],  # filter on just horse racing
            market_countries=['GB'],  # filter on just GB countries
            market_type_codes=['WIN'],  # filter on just WIN market types
        ),
        market_projection=['MARKET_START_TIME', 'RUNNER_DESCRIPTION'],  # runner description required
        max_results=1
    )

    print('%s market catalogues returned' % len(market_catalogues))

# logout
trading.logout()

Part 4:
Market catalogue data contains runner data / metadata, the code below shows how to access this.

import betfairlightweight
from betfairlightweight import filters

# create trading instance
trading = betfairlightweight.APIClient('username', 'password', app_key='appKey')

# login
trading.login()

# make event type request to find horse racing event type
horse_racing_event_type_id = trading.betting.list_event_types(
    filter=filters.market_filter(
        text_query='Horse Racing'
    )
)

# returns one result
print(horse_racing_event_type_id)

for event_type in horse_racing_event_type_id:
    # prints id, name and market count
    print(
        event_type.event_type.id, event_type.event_type.name, event_type.market_count
    )
    horse_racing_id = event_type.event_type.id

    # list all horse racing market catalogues
    market_catalogues = trading.betting.list_market_catalogue(
        filter=filters.market_filter(
            event_type_ids=[horse_racing_id],  # filter on just horse racing
            market_countries=['GB'],  # filter on just GB countries
            market_type_codes=['WIN'],  # filter on just WIN market types
        ),
        market_projection=['MARKET_START_TIME', 'RUNNER_DESCRIPTION'],  # runner description required
        max_results=1
    )

    print('%s market catalogues returned' % len(market_catalogues))

    for market_catalogue in market_catalogues:
        # prints market id, market name and market start time
        print(
            market_catalogue.market_id, market_catalogue.market_name, market_catalogue.market_start_time
        )

        for runner in market_catalogue.runners:
            # prints runner id, runner name and handicap
            print(runner.selection_id, runner.runner_name, runner.handicap)

# logout
trading.logout()

Part 5:
In order to get market/runner data a ‘market book‘ request is required. A list of market id’s are mandatory rather than a market filter as seen in the previous requests.
import betfairlightweight
from betfairlightweight import filters

# create trading instance
trading = betfairlightweight.APIClient('username', 'password', app_key='appKey')

# login
trading.login()

# make event type request to find horse racing event type
horse_racing_event_type_id = trading.betting.list_event_types(
    filter=filters.market_filter(
        text_query='Horse Racing'
    )
)

# returns one result
print(horse_racing_event_type_id)

for event_type in horse_racing_event_type_id:
    # prints id, name and market count
    print(
        event_type.event_type.id, event_type.event_type.name, event_type.market_count
    )
    horse_racing_id = event_type.event_type.id

    # list all horse racing market catalogues
    market_catalogues = trading.betting.list_market_catalogue(
        filter=filters.market_filter(
            event_type_ids=[horse_racing_id],  # filter on just horse racing
            market_countries=['GB'],  # filter on just GB countries
            market_type_codes=['WIN'],  # filter on just WIN market types
        ),
        market_projection=['MARKET_START_TIME', 'RUNNER_DESCRIPTION'],  # runner description required
        max_results=1
    )

    print('%s market catalogues returned' % len(market_catalogues))

    for market_catalogue in market_catalogues:
        # prints market id, market name and market start time
        print(
            market_catalogue.market_id, market_catalogue.market_name, market_catalogue.market_start_time
        )

        for runner in market_catalogue.runners:
            # prints runner id, runner name and handicap
            print(runner.selection_id, runner.runner_name, runner.handicap)

        # market book request
        market_books = trading.betting.list_market_book(
            market_ids=[market_catalogue.market_id]
        )

        for market_book in market_books:
            # prints market id, inplay?, status and total matched
            print(
                market_book.market_id, market_book.inplay, market_book.status, market_book.total_matched
            )

            for runner in market_book.runners:
                # prints selection id, status and total matched
                print(
                    runner.selection_id, runner.status, runner.total_matched
                )

# logout
trading.logout()
Part 6:
In order to receive price data ‘price projection‘ must be added in the market book request.
import betfairlightweight
from bet…
